item.title: Game of the Year 2025 ‚Äì Best Multiplayer Game
Dogpile‚Äôs puzzles mix Balatro, Tetris, and a pile of puppies
item.content:encoded:
One day, video game critics and journalists will put together a comprehensive study on the impact Balatro had on the industry ‚Äî of how so many games that came after tried to capture its essence by adding complex systems to otherwise simple, easily understood games. Until then, I‚Äôm gonna play Dogpile.

Dogpile is a deckbuilding match-3 roguelike that builds on the style of merge games like Suika Game by adding a Balatro-like twist. The result is a cute, cozy (in both genre and vibe) game that appeals to both the numbers-go-up and the dog-loving sicko in me. Drop matching dogs on top of each other to create bigger dogs that reward you with points to unlock higher levels. The smallest unit of dog is a Chihuahua, two Chihuahuas merge to form a Pomeranian (at least that‚Äôs what I think it is), and so forth. The dogs pile up the playing field kinda like Tetris, and also like Tetris, if the dogs spill over the top of the field, it‚Äôs game over.

Merging dogs is the simplest part of the game. It‚Äôs where the player has the least control ‚Äî everything is subject to the whims of gravity, physics, and trajectory ‚Äî but also where Dogpile is the most thrilling. The dogs themselves are cute, contorted into fun, confounding shapes that sometimes show off a butthole or two. Introducing modifiers like making the dogs bouncy or magnetic adds an interesting physical component to the game ‚Äî Dogpile is match-3 Tetris, yes, but built with a physics engine. It feels so silly, so ‚Äúbaby distracted by jangling keys‚Äù to say that a pug glomming onto another pug to make a dachshund is gameplay action worth highlighting in the year of our gaming lord 2025. But the little guy does so with a satisfying ‚Äúpop‚Äù accompanied by a cute little ‚Äúarf‚Äù that like Benoit Blanc, I‚Äôm compelled.

Though the game has nothing to do with poker, you can see the DNA of Balatro running throughout. Like Balatro, each round you‚Äôre dealt a hand from a deck of cards that have dogs as the different suits. Also like Balatro, you get money to spend on modifying your deck with more cards and tags that work similar to Balatro‚Äôs jokers. For $15 (of in-game money, there are no microtransactions), you can either buy a chow chow card or a tag that makes certain dogs spin in place to agitate the dog pile for more merging opportunities. When you win a round, you also visit the grooming salon where you modify your dog cards directly. You can give a dog positive traits like ‚Äúfriendly,‚Äù making them magnetically attracted to their matches. Or you can wash away negative traits like fleas, which negate any positive traits a card might have.

Building your dog deck full of synergies to increase your points is where Dogpile is the most like Balatro and where the bulk of your strategic thinking comes into play. I like to give my dogs the barking trait that makes them disturb the pile with a bark when they‚Äôre dropped. That combined with the tag that awards points every time a dog barks makes for a brain-pleasing display of meters filling up and cash register noises going off that really drives home the fact that a lot of these well-intentioned, celebrated Balatro-likes tap into the psychology of gambling addition to make them stick.

Dogpile doesn‚Äôt feel very deep. There are no boss challenges. Failing to meet the point threshold doesn‚Äôt end a run, but instead makes you pick from a stock of negative events or traits that are either easily ignored or so detrimental that you lose the game immediately. Unlike Balatro, Dogpile doesn‚Äôt inspire the same feeling of endless possibility of the kinds of decks you can build.

Dogpile isn‚Äôt the first game to complexify the humble match-3 genre, and I don‚Äôt know if its similarities to Balatro are intentional or not. But I like seeing how games can push Balatro‚Äôs formula beyond poker ‚Äî especially if a dog is involved.

And yes, you can pet them.

Dogpile is out now on Steam.

item.title: You can buy your Xbox Ally an official pair of anti-drift joysticks
item.content:encoded:
Even at $1,000, the Xbox Ally X handheld didn‚Äôt ship with magnetic drift-resistant joysticks, and neither did the $600 model. But for an extra $20 at Amazon, you can change that today ‚Äî with officially Asus-approved and sanctioned TMR joysticks from Gulikit, the company that‚Äôs made a name for itself by supplying aftermarket drift-resistant sticks.

The company says it worked with Xbox Ally manufacturer Asus to create these sticks, that they‚Äôll be ‚Äúautomatically recognized‚Äù when you swap them in, and that you can use the handheld‚Äôs built-in Armoury Crate app to calibrate them afterwards.

And while I haven‚Äôt tried these ones (I do have a pair in my Switch), I can confirm it‚Äôs pretty easy to pop open the Xbox Ally to install. Just loosen the Philips-head screws, poke in a guitar pick pry tool to create a small gap, and pull a little harder than you think you need to pop open the clips. The joystick modules are right underneath. There‚Äôs nothing blocking you ‚Äî just pop a ribbon cable and undo their three screws.

Here‚Äôs the company‚Äôs walkthrough in case you want to see for yourself ‚Äî though I do not recommend taking sharp tweezers to ribbon cables when your fingernails can do that job safer and easier. (I may have broken a few ribbon cables in my life.)

When we‚Äôre talking about TMR or the older and slightly less power-efficient Hall effect joystick technology, I usually write ‚Äúdrift-resistant‚Äù instead of ‚Äúdrift-free‚Äù because you may find your center point drifting over time ‚Äî but the beauty of magnetic is you just have to recalibrate! Unlike the potentiometer joysticks that ship with Nintendo, Sony PlayStation, and Microsoft Xbox controllers, you‚Äôre not scraping away material that‚Äôll lead to permanent drift as you use the magnetic versions.

Gulikit‚Äôs new Xbox Ally sticks are $20 in the US today, and should also be available in the UK for ¬£20, and in Italy, France, and Spain for ‚Ç¨22, this January.

item.title: Battlefield 6 tweaks "vehicle availability" across Breakthrough maps for attackers and defenders
item.content:encoded:
"If we find that these changes are not performing well, we are prepared to rollback."

Battlefield 6 is changing vehicle availability on its Breakthrough maps to improve pacing and "vehicle availability" for attackers and defenders.

The changes, coming first to New Sobek City, are "part of a set of changes across multiple Breakthrough maps", and will be "actively monitor[ed]" to assess how they impact gameplay.

"Over the last few days, we‚Äôve been rolling out a set of changes across multiple Breakthrough maps, starting with our earlier test on New Sobek City," the team explained in a social media post. "These changes are aimed at improving overall pacing and vehicle availability between Attacker and Defenders, and we are actively monitoring how these changes are impacting gameplay."

Interestingly, the team is transparent that these change may not "perform well", but did commit to roll[ing] back some or all of these changes as our focus remains on steadily improving Breakthrough overall".

The team closed on thanking players for their "patience, support, and feedback as we continue to tune the mode", hinted further updates would be coming in the New Year, and wished everyone "happy holidays".

The last big update came earlier this month, when Battlefield 6 received both netcode and hit registration improvements ahead of the Winter Offensive update, which went live on the 9th December. It's part of the team's wider work to enhance both components of online play and is especially noteworthy, as issues with online netcode and hit registration have been sources of frustration for some players since launch.

This update came shortly after EA revealed that close to 98 percent of its games post-launch were cheater-free, as well as a week-long free-to-play offering that allowed folks to try the military FPS out without breaking the bank.

item.title: ‚ÄòFriend slop‚Äô made co-op gaming goofier than ever in 2025
item.content:encoded:
When a friend invited me to play a new game called REPO earlier this year, I thought I was wasting my money ‚Äî not because the game looked bad, but because it looked like Lethal Company. The surprise-hit 2024 co-op survival horror game has players wander through unnerving ruined structures collecting trash while evading monsters. Lethal Company was popular with my friends (and just about everyone else), but its eerie liminal spaces spooked me too much. My friends swore REPO was different, though, that it was so funny it was hard to be scared, especially with its goofy robot avatars ‚Äî and they were right.

REPO has become one of my favorite games, and was one of the biggest co-op titles of 2025, along with similar indie co-op hit Peak. Over the past several months, the two titles have become the faces of a new niche of games with a somewhat controversial name: ‚Äúfriend slop.‚Äù

The term usually refers to indie co-op games that are best experienced with friends and have an emphasis on humor. They‚Äôre typically PC games, cost less than $20, include proximity voice chat, feature wacky game physics, and often fall into the survival horror genre. Friend slop isn‚Äôt always scary, though. Some lighthearted flavors of ‚Äúslop‚Äù popped up this year, like Peak, where you attempt to scale increasingly perilous mountains with your friends.

That‚Äôs just the tip ‚Äî or rather, peak ‚Äî of the friend slop iceberg. There‚Äôs also Guilty as Sock!, where you and your co-op buddies roleplay court showdowns as sock puppets. Lockdown Protocol takes inspiration from Among Us, a precursor to the friend slop trend, where one player attempts to sabotage their friends as they complete chores on a timer in a lonely base. Mage Arena is one of the cheapest friend slop games to arrive this year at just $2.99. It‚Äôs also one of the most unique ‚Äî you compete in magic duels with your friends by verbally shouting spells.

Friend slop games tend to follow a similar formula: You and your friends need to accomplish something together, but the consequences for failure aren‚Äôt particularly intense (and it‚Äôs often funnier if you don‚Äôt succeed). Peak is a perfect example. I have yet to survive to the end of a run, and yet I keep playing. Winning Peak is great, but the most entertaining part is watching your friends miss a jump and fall off a mountain, eat poisonous food, or get chased down by the scoutmaster for running ahead.

In friend slop, the main objective is humor. Winning is secondary. If you‚Äôre hoping for a deep, nuanced plot, you‚Äôll probably be disappointed. Friend slop games also tend to lose their charm when you‚Äôre playing solo. REPO just isn‚Äôt the same when there‚Äôs no one there to laugh every time you clumsily shatter a vase.

Therein lies one of the major criticisms of the genre and one of the reasons it‚Äôs been labeled ‚Äúslop‚Äù to begin with. While REPO and Peak have been hugely popular this year, some say they‚Äôre just designed for viral, clippable moments and lack substance beyond that, partly because they‚Äôre not usually fun to play solo.

That could be a fair drawback depending on what you expect from these games. However, it misses the point of ‚Äúfriend slop‚Äù and overlooks a potential explanation for their popularity this year.

Elden Ring Nightreign was also one of 2025‚Äôs biggest co-op games, and I‚Äôve had a great time with it as well. However, it offers something completely different from REPO or Peak and feels drastically different to play, despite technically being under the same broad co-op umbrella. Nightreign requires concentration, skill, and strategy, whereas REPO mostly just requires you to keep an eye out for monsters while absentmindedly picking up junk. It‚Äôs also a much more affordable game than Nightreign and doesn‚Äôt hinge on any prior knowledge of other games.

That difference highlights one of friend slop‚Äôs greatest strengths. For all their arguable faults, friend slop games are approachable. They ask little of you ‚Äî both in terms of money and time. You don‚Äôt even need a particularly powerful PC. These games are a way for people to hang out with friends for little money and laugh with each other. To some, myself included, that‚Äôs worth just as much as a rich story or dramatic boss fights.

This year, we‚Äôve seen the prices of games soar, and gaming PC hardware is becoming unaffordable for many. Almost everything about the hobby has become more expensive. Friend slop games offer an oasis from that with low prices and low hardware requirements, staying accessible to a large swath of gamers, even more so because they‚Äôre typically easy to learn how to play. The very things that led some people to call these games ‚Äúslop‚Äù are also part of what has made them so popular in 2025 in particular.

Paige Wilson, community manager at Peak publisher Aggro Crab, echoed that sentiment. ‚ÄúWe actually think friend slop is a fire term,‚Äù they told The Verge. ‚ÄúSure, it started with the intention of [having] a negative connotation, but I think we always saw the term as funny and actually pretty accurate. It‚Äôs used to describe a low-cost game that you and your friends can pick up whenever, have some fun, hang out, and expect a bit of jank. I think some people might not view it as this, but we do!‚Äù

In other words, friend slop isn‚Äôt so much about the game as it is about the people you play it with. If that‚Äôs ‚Äúslop,‚Äù then I‚Äôll gladly embrace the ‚Äúfriend slop‚Äù label, too.

item.title: Review: Despelote (Switch) - An Irresistible And Appropriately Beautiful Game
item.content:encoded:
Editor's note: This game launched in North America on 11th December, but won't hit European eShops until 13th January.

For some, football is something to play; for some, it‚Äôs something to watch; for others, it‚Äôs something to be scared of in the playground. But in 2001, in Ecuador, football meant just about everything to just about everyone. At least, that‚Äôs the story told by Despelote, a game that conjures the magic of childhood and football fever and makes it captivatingly relatable.

The game opens with you playing video soccer on an old console. As it‚Äôs gradually revealed that you‚Äôre sitting in a family living room, your parents‚Äô chatter creeping into your awareness, you are connected very intimately with the protagonist of the game ‚Äî its designer ‚Äî Juli√°n, a kid in Ecuador in 2001.

That year, Ecuador clinched a game against Peru, starting a journey towards first-time World Cup qualification, and everyone‚Äôs there for it. Your family are watching football, school kids are playing football at break time, overheard grown-up conversations are about football, and it‚Äôs blaring on TVs in bars and shop windows. The sense of optimism brewing around this national event permeates every aspect of life and it‚Äôs impossible not to be swept up in it.

This historic moment fixes the story in place and time, creating a little bubble of childhood. The nostalgia is flavoured with small adventures, like skipping school to take in the glorious scenery of Ecuador, aggravating your teacher, and playing out too long in the rain.

Gameplay-wise, this is all delivered in a variety of ways. That opening moment of playing on the console gives you a top-down, black-and-white football game, controlled with an innovative two-stick arrangement. The game then moves into first person, your ‚Äúreal-world‚Äù playtime football-kicking coming to mirror the console game‚Äôs controls. From this perspective, you sit in class, check your watch, skip school, talk to your friends, and, yes, kick around a football.

Much of the time, you're just an observer, building the sense of being a kid and following whatever is set out for you by the adults in your life. You listen to lessons while you wait for the bell; you ride in the back seat and hear conversations happening in the front. Among the passive moments are a variety of first-person interactions, almost always involving or adjacent to football.

Despelote doesn‚Äôt try to riff on a central mechanic. In place of that, it develops themes of memory and childhood through a range of gameplay approaches. This keeps the experience light while making the excitement about the football feel totally irresistible. However you look at it, however you interact with it, everything is football. From Juli√°n Cordero‚Äôs perspective, everything orbits around football, but other key moments in Ecuador‚Äôs history play out, too, from dollarisation to the country‚Äôs first showing at the Venice Film Festival.

This gameplay-light approach does mean Despelote asks for a certain mindset. This isn‚Äôt a game driven by challenge, mastery, or meaningful choice, and there are long stretches where your role is simply to exist in the moment it presents. Progress is gentle, more like turning a page of a book than developing gameplay, and the designer is happier letting scenes wash over you than pushing you forward. If you‚Äôre willing to meet it on those terms, the restraint feels purposeful; if not, this gentle vignette may feel too far from a traditional game.

Visually, the game could hardly be more distinctive. The art, by Sebasti√°n Valbuena, sees figures drawn by hand in black outlines on white backgrounds making up the cast of the game. They sit on top of hazily dithered two-tone scenes. This effect layered on top of the 3D environment completely disguises the level of detail in the world, its lighting and textures ‚Äì almost anything that might normally contribute to overall visual impressions.

The graphics are therefore, in a sense, flawless. The art direction is expressed to its full, love it or hate it. In motion, it comes to life in a way screenshots can‚Äôt convey, and once you're immersed, the world is living and breathing. This is helped by the voicing of all dialogue and the inclusion of real video of football matches, displayed through the same vibrant filter.

All the spoken language is Spanish, with English speech bubbles written out onscreen. This adds beautifully to the sense of place and authenticity; I was transported to Ecuador and my imagination ran with it. Meanwhile, active sound effects and incidental sounds lift the realism of the world. Music is relatively sparse and often diegetic, with key moments of wistful guitar ‚Äì but this contributes to a matter-of-fact tone that doesn‚Äôt overegg the emotional heart of the story. And an emotional response is what the game is all about. Yes, football provides a pitch for it to play on, but this is a relatable story even to someone with no interest in the sport.

A slightly dry tone also makes room for some light humour. With Despelote, Cordero doesn‚Äôt take himself too seriously. A lack of self-importance places the protagonist as just one thread in the tapestry, which again builds a sense of a moment in history. A remembered story is always one you can‚Äôt alter, so drifting through this autobiographical account makes total sense. That said, if you‚Äôre looking for greater agency or action, maybe this won‚Äôt quite be for you.

It‚Äôs to Cordero‚Äôs credit that they also knew when to stop. The game tells its story without padding, then ties it in a bow and bids farewell after just a couple of hours. It lands as a complete work and can‚Äôt be criticised for being short ‚Äì but bear in mind that this is not some open-ended adventure.

Conclusion

With its distinctive presentation and light-touch mechanics, Despelote builds a mesmerising feeling of a community brought together by a fleeting football obsession. The historic moment of Ecuador‚Äôs journey towards World Cup qualification grounds the story in time and place, perfectly capturing the author‚Äôs salad days. Whether you play, watch, or avoid football, this is a beautifully-told story you can enjoy.

item.title: The sold-out Nex Playground made my kids laugh and cry
item.content:encoded:
If you told me last year the Nex Playground would outsell Microsoft‚Äôs Xbox, even for two weeks, I would have laughed my way out of the room.

It‚Äôs a three-inch cube of a game console that‚Äôs likely less powerful than your phone, one which uses a single camera to track your body. It only plays curated, certified kid-safe games. Though frequently compared to the Nintendo Wii and Microsoft Kinect, the Nex Playground is worse than either at tracking motion.

Nor is it cheap: $250 upfront plus $89-a-year or $49-a-quarter annual subscription to get more than a basic sampler. If you like a game, you can‚Äôt buy it separately. Many are little better than shovelware and most are graphically ugly; I haven‚Äôt tried a single game with the charm or polish of Nintendo or the best of Apple Arcade.

And yet, lying sick in bed with a 99-degree fever, my five-year-old begged me to let her play.

When we started a game of virtual bowling, even Grandpa wanted in. (Grandpa never wants in.)

‚ÄúI want to try again!‚Äù said my nine-year-old, after she sent her low-rent airplane plummeting to its doom.

They didn‚Äôt care that the games were bad. They cared that they were dead simple to pick up and play, no controller and no experience necessary, on a big screen. They cared that the games made them dance and jump and swing their arms, and that their dad looked pretty funny doing the same.

I just wish the games didn‚Äôt make them cry, too.

Nearly 20 years ago, the Nintendo Wii put an infrared camera and an accelerometer in your hand to tell if you moved your arm fast, slow, closer or further, and track basic orientation. A few years later, Microsoft‚Äôs Kinect captured your whole body with no controller at all: it painted your room with a structured pattern of infrared light to estimate your skeletal position in 3D space.

The Playground is different: a single wide-angle camera up front and HDMI and USB-C power around back, nothing else to plug in. But it also doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúsee‚Äù 3D depth. It has to estimate your body pose from flat images.

Sometimes, it‚Äôs impressive: by identifying just six joints ‚Äî shoulders, elbows, hands ‚Äî you can throw a bowling ball straight down the lane or veer it left and right. But with no real depth perception, it can easily get confused: my nine-year-old couldn‚Äôt sit on the couch while my five-year-old was bowling several feet ahead, because the Playground assumed all their limbs belonged to the same person. My youngest cried for several minutes when the eldest raised a hand and accidentally stole her turn.

Soon it was the eldest‚Äôs turn to cry, too, when the Playground lost her hand mid-swing and sent her ball careening into the gutter. She got mad when it happened again.

There are so many things that can confuse single-camera tracking, and Nex knows it. Warnings include: Don‚Äôt wear clothing with repeating patterns. Don‚Äôt wear long sleeves. Play in a well-lit room, but not backlit. ‚ÄúAvoid non-players in the camera view.‚Äù

These all help a single camera tell people from their background ‚Äî but parents know some are harder than they sound! Our kids get game time after their evening bath, which means PJs. Have you seen kids‚Äô PJs? They have long sleeves and repeating patterns. Hearts. Stars. Smiley faces. Repeating cats and unicorns till the cows come home.

We had to roll up sleeves and rethink seating. Realistically, ‚ÄúAvoid non-players in the camera view‚Äù meant clearing the entire living room of anyone who wasn‚Äôt bowling, having them stand far off to the side, so that the camera didn‚Äôt suddenly snap to the wrong person mid-play. Sometimes we could sit on the couch with hands hidden behind blankets or laptops.

Even so, my kids frequently got too frustrated with the controls. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt keep my hand steady! I just can‚Äôt keep it steady!‚Äù complained my five-year-old, trying to send her cute puppy for a spa treatment in Nex‚Äôs Nintendogs-like game. Many games don‚Äôt penalize kids for swinging their arms wildly, but some inexplicably require dragging a cursor to press virtual buttons.

It also feels like the Playground lags behind my movements, even plugged directly into a low-latency OLED TV with Game Mode turned on. In Nex‚Äôs kart racer game, I couldn‚Äôt turn the steering wheel as fast as I wanted in its fastest 150cc mode.

Again, the issues didn‚Äôt stop us from having fun, particularly when with games that don‚Äôt require precision. The kids had a blast with Mirrorama, which turns your TV into a giant mirror with magical camera filters that let kids shoot lightning bolts from their hands, stretch their face, blur like as speedy as Sonic the Hedgehog, dance with their own clone.

Mirrorama, above, made my kids laugh the most.

They enjoyed Copy Cat, where they just had to strike a zany cartoon pose and let AI judge who did it better. Meanwhile, I found Brick Buster to be an excellent Breakout clone ‚Äî you only need move your body left or right to move the paddle, which is forgivingly large, and thrilling multiball action makes it fun.

I can‚Äôt say we‚Äôd get our money‚Äôs worth, though, because so many games are simple and inanely repetitive, or ‚Äî like Connect 4 Bounce, where my kid and I gave up trying to get balls to even go in ‚Äî frustrating from the get-go. Many sports games are either laughably easy or have a large learning curve because the camera can‚Äôt see depth, so it can‚Äôt detect how you‚Äôre hitting a ball. With tennis, for example, you can‚Äôt aim with your arm: it only controls the timing of your swing. You have to move the rest of your body to aim left or right.

One of Nex‚Äôs biggest marketing points is that it‚Äôs already attracted huge kid brands to the platform: Bluey, Peppa Pig, Gabby‚Äôs Dollhouse, Sesame Street, How to Train Your Dragon, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. But my kids weren‚Äôt necessarily sold.

Bluey, is one of the better licensed experiences ‚Äî but my Bluey-loving kids weren‚Äôt that into it.

They seemed entranced at first with Unicorn Academy, but quickly disappointed when they couldn‚Äôt ride the unicorn anywhere interesting. The TMNT game is a frustrating endless runner where you constantly have to hop into the air to clear obstacles, though I suppose it could help tire out my kids. And even though they love Bluey, my kids quickly asked me to quit its too-repetitive balloon-bouncing game.

There‚Äôs enough in the Playground‚Äôs library that I bet your kids will find something they enjoy. My eldest wants to go visit her puppy, and the other night at dinner, my youngest erupted into cheers of ‚ÄúBowling!!! I love bowling!!!‚Äù when we said we might play it again. Despite countless tracking failures, they say that Nex‚Äôs Flappy Bird clone, where up to four people hop in the air to keep their dragons eating fruit instead of crashing into towers, is one of their favs.

I think the Playground is far too much money for not nearly enough game. But it goes to show fun isn‚Äôt all about quality of execution. Many classic arcade games are frustratingly unfair, even broken ‚Äî but sometimes you just want another turn to beat the machine.

item.title: Talking Point: What Are You Playing This Weekend? (20th December)
item.content:encoded:
Ah yes, the weekend. Not just any ol' weekend either! No, it's the weekend before Christmas, which means it's time to start preparing your stomachs for an avalanche of food and chocolate.

This week in the world of Nintendo, it seems that there may be an alternative to those ruddy Game Key Cards after an announcement from ININ Games. We also received a lovely new Switch 2 Edition of Divinity: Original Sin 2 from Larian Studios, so hopefully this is a little precursor of things to come from the acclaimed developer.

We also heard some rather grim news confirming that the US had its worst November since 1995 in terms of hardware sales, which may be partially attributed to just how darn expensive everything is these days. In lighter news, however, the highly-anticipated Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade received a free demo on the Switch 2 eShop, so be sure to give it a shot if you're interested!

Jim Norman, Staff Writer

The Christmas spirit is well and truly underway at Casa Jim this weekend, so I‚Äôll be bringing out the big guns with Super Mario Party Jamboree and Nintendo Switch Sports. As has become something of a tradition in recent years, I‚Äôll probably end up dusting off the Wii U GamePad and setting up a few rounds of Nintendo Land to keep everyone happy ‚Äî they just don‚Äôt make ‚Äòem like this any more!

Sure, I technically still have a bunch of 2025 games that I‚Äôd like to finish before the year is up, but hey, that‚Äôs not very festive now is it?

Ollie Reynolds, Staff Writer

I'm checking out Layers of Fear: The Final Masterpiece Edition on the Switch 2 at the moment, so please keep an eye out for my review very soon!

Otherwise, since I've pretty much finalised my list for Game of the Year, I'm in no hurry to try and play games that I might have missed over the months. With that in mind, I'm going to go back to something familiar and comforting... Yes, Resident Evil ‚Äì how did you know?

Gon√ßalo Lopes, Contributor

My head has been up in the (virtual) clouds since the VGA announcement of Ace Combat 8: The Wings of Theve so I got back into Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown, a game that is begging for a Switch 2 update. The final physical games arrived so there will also be some Mandragora: Whispers of the Witch Tree and Old School Rally thrown into the rotation along with Halo: The Master Chief Collection (on my way to Halo 3 now!).

Game of the week is Yakuza Kiwami 2. It is my goal to wrap it up before 2026. So far up to chapter 9 and loving every bit of it. It reminds me we are but two shy months away from Kiwami 3! Happy holidays everyone!

Kate Gray, Contributor

I'm playing... oh dear. The same games as last week. Aren't I boring. That's Outer Worlds 2, Hades II, and Astro Prospector. They're good! And I don't have the brainpower for anything new in the run-up to Christmas!

I'm also playing through the festive content in Hello Kitty Island Adventure, but that's because I wrote a lot of it, so... does that count? Probably not. Also, does this count as self-promotion? Am I in trouble? Please don't give me a lump of coal. Or whatever the Nintendo Life version of that is.

Alex Olney, Video Producer

My weekend should be pretty full this side of Christmas (we're having duck), but if I manage to find some time to squeeze in a game or two, I'll definitely be diving into Layers of Fear: The Final Masterpiece Edition. I loved the original, but never delved into anything beyond the base game, so I'm keen to see what this new version can throw at me.

Felix and I are also planning to continue our time with We Were Here Together at some point as well, but that is... unlikely to happen over the immediate weekend.

Alana Hagues, Deputy Editor

Octopath Traveler 0 is going to take Zach and I a long time to get through. We're maybe 35 hours through and the town building has only just opened up more. How long do we have left? No idea, and that's kind of exciting!

But for the holidays, I've picked up Tiny Bookshop and despelote. The latter I've been waiting to come to Switch for a while, and the former seems like perfect cosy Christmas gaming. However you celebrate, readers, make time for your loved ones and get some rest!

Well, that's what we have planned for this weekend, but what about you? Let us know your picks in the following poll.

item.content:encoded:
"We're back to take out the bugs"

Following the release of the beat 'em up Marvel Cosmic Invasion on the Switch and Switch 2 earlier this month, a new update for the title has now been rolled out.

It‚Äôs time for an upgrade! If you drop into the fight in MARVEL Cosmic Invasion you‚Äôll find a new update, packed with fixes and quality-of-life tweaks. This bug-blasting patch is live now on all platforms, so suit up, jump in and get back into the fight, Super Heroes!

Bug Fixes

  • We‚Äôve fixed an issue which would prevent the ‚ÄúSpecial Attack Assemble‚Äù achievement from triggering in online modes
  • We‚Äôve given Wolverine and She-Hulk a pep talk - fixing their grab attack and stopping them from freezing mid action.
  • We‚Äôve fixed Annihilus moving out of view if his armor is broken by She-Hulk‚Äôs Spinning throw
  • We‚Äôve also stopped Annihilus from become intangible if his armor is broken by Wolverine‚Äôs grab and slash attack
  • We‚Äôve fixed missing subtitles for Spider-Man‚Äôs first post-Annihilus battle dialogue
  • We‚Äôve fixed a blocker that meant the last player couldn‚Äôt pick an already-selected Super Hero in Arcade Mode (even if the Doppleganger modifier was turned on)
  • We‚Äôve fixed an issue where move lists were displaying incorrectly in multiplayer, if Player One was using a keyboard
  • We‚Äôve also had a chat with Hela to ensure she doesn‚Äôt get bored and go idle if host players leave a multiplayer game during the fight
  • We‚Äôve also fixed achievement-related freezes on Windows and Xbox, as well as various crash issues on PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch and Nintendo Switch 2

Smaller Fixes

  • We‚Äôve fixed an issue that was making it impossible to change Super Hero‚Äôs colour profile after hitting Continue for Arcade mode
  • We‚Äôve fixed the life bar showing incorrect costumes when changing characters
  • We‚Äôve made sure that feedback is shown correctly when Super Heroes run out of ammo
  • We‚Äôve also fixed an issue where over-time damage numbers from Phyla-Vell‚Äôs cosmic damage was not displaying correctly in multiplayer
  • We‚Äôve fixed character select inconsistencies which could cause Super Hero icons to be incorrectly greyed out

Whatever platform it has come from, we wanted to say thank you to all the Super Heroes out there who are joining the fight in MARVEL Cosmic Invasion and have come to give us feedback. The detail you‚Äôve provided has been instrumental in helping us to squash these bugs.

The MARVEL Cosmic Invasion team at Tribute Games and Dotemu

Plenty of other games have been getting in their final updates of 2025 in this week. This includes both first and third-party titles for the Switch and Switch 2. If you want to find out more about Cosmic Invasion, check out our review here on Nintendo Life.

item.title: Nex Playground Boss Says The Console Solves The Wii "Problem"
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

While Sony and Nintendo have expanded their lead over Xbox, a dark horse console had a very strong showing in third place in November. The Nex Playground has emerged as a breakout hit, and CEO David Lee believes that one of the reasons why its been so successful is because the console has solved the Wii "problem."

Nearly two decades ago, the Wii powered Nintendo's post-GameCube comeback with its motion controls and unique games. Lee argues that the scope of Wii's success made it difficult to sustain in the long term. Instead of trying to sell games like Wii, Nex Playground is offering its titles as part of a subscription service.

"One of the most important things we should do is learn from history and try not to commit the same limitations, and that's why we have a subscription model," Lee told The Game Business. "Nintendo expanded the audience with Wii. When you expand the audience, and they want different things, and they only buy Wii Fit, Wii Sports and not many others ‚Ä¶ that's a bit of a problem."

Lee was very complementary toward Nintendo in his follow-up remarks, but he added that the Wii's model of selling only a few games to certain members of its install base was "not sustainable."

"It's very important that we set ourselves up to serve our customer continuously with new innovations," added Lee. "That is how the whole system can sustain. But it started with Wii. We are standing on a giant‚Äôs shoulder."

Nex Playground reportedly accounted for 14% of all console sales on Black Friday, finishing ahead of the Xbox family of systems.

Have you ever dreamed of being a Pokemon researcher? If so, you'll need to do some studying to become a bonafide expert in the field of pocket monsters, and that's where this informative book comes into play. Pokecology: An Illustrated Guide to Pokemon Ecology is an official book that explores the habitats of the famous monsters, and you can add it to your list of study materials for just $15 ahead of its release on April 21, 2026.

Pokecology: An Illustrated Guide to Pokemon Ecology

$15 | Releases April 21, 2026

The Pokecology explores the ecologies of Pokemon based on data from the Pokedex. The 208-page book is full of visuals that examine the similarities, differences, generalities, and relationships between Pokemon ecologies, and Chihiro Kinoshita, a real-life expert in animal behavior and ecosystems, has illustrated it. The book is also officially licensed by The Pokemon Company, as it's produced through its publishing imprint, Pikachu Press.

For more Pokemon academia, you can also check out Pokemon: The Complete Pocket Guide Volume 1 and Volume 2. The first 560-page volume covers Pokedex entries No. 1 through 442, and the 552-page Volume 2 covers Pok√©mon 443 through 898 on the National Pokedex. This is a fairly comprehensive list, but you won't find Pokemon from the Paldean region of Pokemon Scarlet and Violet listed here. The nice thing about these books is that they're designed to be pocket-friendly and they're also available as part of a two-book box set. Each Pokemon is accompanied by details on its stats, abilities, moves, and evolutions.

Priced at $70, it'll be released for Switch 2 consoles on March 5, 2026.

item.title: Sorcery: Contested Realm Review - Innovative and Old School
item.content:encoded:
You are an Avatar, floating in the void. By your power alone you can mold the earth beneath you, from scorching deserts to shifting seas. But there is another Avatar, a foe contesting the realm. Will you have the magic, wits, and minions to survive? That‚Äôs the question posed to you when you shuffle up your decks and play Sorcery: Contested Realm, a Trading Card Game created by Erik's Curiosa.

Sorcery: Contested Realm is a collectible TCG created in 2024 by Erik‚Äôs Curiosa, which aims to capture the old-school feel of classic trading card games like Magic: The Gathering.

From incredible, oil-painted artwork (of which all the artists retain the rights to their work!), to a ‚ÄúKitchen Table TCG‚Äù design philosophy, the game aims to capture what it felt like to first crack packs of early-days TCG‚Äôs and jump into a strange and enchanting world.

The rules are designed to be simple, but there‚Äôs plenty of tactical strategy involved to encourage players to experiment with deck-building and different approaches to battle.

How Do You Play Sorcery: Contested Realm?

To play the game, each player will need an Avatar of their choosing, a deck of 30 Atlas Cards, and a deck of 50 Spellbook cards, as well as a play mat or gaming surface divided into a 4x5 grid.

There are four different elements (you guessed it: earth, wind, air, and fire) which each give different flavor to cards, and require different types of Site cards played on the field to power up. 

You‚Äôll use your Avatar to play these Site cards onto the battlefield, cast spells, attack enemy Site cards with minions, and attempt to bring your opponent‚Äôs health down to 0 - which triggers a tense end-game as you move your forces in for the kill.

Wait‚Ä¶ did I just say move?

How Does It Feel To Play Sorcery: Contested Realm?

One of the most exciting aspects of Sorcery: Contested Realm is the way you battle on the board. You‚Äôll actually move your minions and Avatar around the playing field (once you‚Äôve placed cards down that serve as realms across the vast void), attacking, defending, and trying to close the gap on your opponent. This adds a thrilling mix of troop movement into your usual TCG game.

In a way, it almost feels like you‚Äôre playing a smaller, approachable version of a tabletop war-game in the middle of your classic TCG. This reliance on physical placement of cards on the board adds a truly unique feel to the game - with some Spells shooting out in a straight line. There are also ways to destroy your opponent's Site cards, or in other ways hinder your enemy's movement.

Attacking feels familiar to games like Magic, where your Minions deal damage equal to their strength to your opponent's Minions - but there's a unique mechanic here, too, where nearby allied Minions can swoop in to help defend. It all leads to much more movement around the board than you'd expect at first glance (most Minions and Avatars can only move one space per activation). It all feels familiar and refreshingly new at the same time. Just like the artwork on the cards.

The Art of Sorcery: Contested Realm

As you've likely noticed from the imagery so far in this review, the artwork on display for Sorcery: Contested Realm is unique, iconic, and captures a feeling I miss from modern TCG games: that hand-made feeling. 

I'm not saying games like Magic and Pokemon can't have gorgeous card art - they more often than not do - but overall there's a slickness to the images that leaves them feeling less personal.

With Sorcery: Contested Realm all of the artwork is, to quote their own site (where they proudly devote an entire page to speaking in depth about the art and artists), "hand-painted using traditional mediums such as oil, acrylic, water color paintings, pen and pencil, or a mix of all the various media. This creates a very authentic and varied feel within the art, evoking the golden age of fantasy."

That's my favorite part of the Sorcery artwork, every card looks different. That feels like old-school TCG games to me, where there's no unified set of design imperatives all the artists have to adhere to. It feels free, wild, and evokes the varied magic being flung around the void in Sorcery.

Learning The Game

The game's core rules and concepts are very easy to pick up on if you're a veteran of trading card games already. You'll understand core mechanics like needing resources to play cards, tapping things to attack/gain effects, etc. If you're brand new to trading card games, you will need to do a bit of catch up - as Sorcery: Contested Realm takes the foundations built over the last 30 years of gaming and adds on it with "troop movement" (for lack of a better term).

My only complaint with the game is also something I love about it - go figure! That's this "kitchen table" approach to gaming, meaning there are some elements that flavorful, but not clearly defined (especially in the starter set's quickstart rulebook). And while that leads to a little extra flipping back and forth through the core rules, I'd imagine it also opens the game up to more creative ideation in the future.

Where To Start With Sorcery: Contested Realm

As I just mentioned above, Sorcery: Contested Realm currently has three sets out: the core set, Arthurian Legends, and the just released set: Gothic. If you want to get a good feel of the game, I highly recommend picking up one of their two Starter Sets - The Four Elements Starter Set comes from the core set, and features four mini-decks each attuned to one of the four elements. 

It's a great way to get a taste of the game. The new The Prophets of Doom Starter Set was just released with the release of Gothic, and features four decks attuned to angels, demons, and other gleefully grim cards from the new set.

Sorcery: Contested Realm - Final Thoughts

I've wanted to try Sorcery: Contested Realm for a while now based just on hearing rumbling about it in the TCG community, and I'm so glad I did! Sorcery is one of the biggest surprises of the year for me, completely blowing away my expectations. The artwork on display is unlike anything else in the TCG world today, and the gameplay feels fluid, satisfying, and tactical. 

If you're a fan of classic fantasy artwork and you're looking for a new game to try as your other faves get filled with outside IP's, chase ultra-shiny mega rares, and more bloat -- you should absolutely give Sorcery: Contested Realm a spin! You won't be disappointed.

On Friday, retro and arcade game publisher ININ Games surprisingly announced it‚Äôs been able to ‚Äúrecalculate production‚Äù on offering a physical version of R-Type Dimensions III for the Switch 2 because ‚ÄúTwo days ago Nintendo announced two new smaller cartridge sizes for Nintendo Switch 2.‚Äù Physical games on the Switch 2 have been something of a contentious topic; full physical games are reportedly expensive for developers, while game-key cards don‚Äôt actually have the game on the cart.

But later in the day, ININ removed that line from its post and published a significant correction: ‚ÄúThere has been no official announcement or confirmation from Nintendo concerning cartridge storage capacities. Any references to specific storage sizes should not be interpreted as official information from Nintendo.‚Äù However, it will still be able to offer the physical Switch 2 version of R-Type Dimensions III, though by tacking on ‚Ç¨10 to the retail price.

Nintendo didn‚Äôt immediately reply to a request for comment. Solid information about why more developers don‚Äôt offer games fully on-cartridge is hard to find, though it may come down to cost. In May, a Brazilian Nintendo journalist reported that, based on leaks from Arc System Works, Nintendo only offered two types of physical games for developers: a 64GB cartridge and the game-key card. The YouTube channel Physical Paradise has also reported that the cost of a physical cartridge is ‚Äúabout‚Äù $16, ‚Äúwhich is quite expensive.‚Äù

Niko Partners analyst Daniel Ahmad, replying to ININ Games‚Äô initial announcement about the new cartridge sizes, said on X that ‚Äúcost was always the primary factor between key cards vs full cart releases.‚Äù

Do you know the actual cost of Switch 2 cartridges?

It‚Äôs unclear exactly how much more affordable additional cartridge capacity sizes could be or why the company might offer them to developers now. item.title: James Ohlen Steps Down from Archetype Entertainment, Remains as Consultant with Wizards of the Coast
item.content:encoded:
A change-up has happened at Archetype Entertainment. The lead of the studio, James Ohlen, will be stepping down from the company, shifting his role within the parent company, Wizards of the Coast.

According to a report by EN World, James Ohlen has chosen to leave his position as the lead of Archetype Entertainment. This is a new internal games studio established by tabletop giant Wizards of the Coast to develop AAA videogames based on original IPs.

This is important since the studio's first project, Exodus, has been long in development. After its 2023 announcement, a lot of pre-rendered trailers, a dedicated episode in the anthology series Secret Level, and an official TTRPG tie-in, the sci-fi title had a gameplay trailer at this year's The Game Awards. The game appears to be a narrative-focused third-person action title. It also dropped a release date of early 2027.

Ohlen's official reasons for his departure from Archetype Entertainment were that he felt that his work on Exodus was complete and that the final bits of development were in good hands. Given the nature of videogame development cycles, this tracks. It means the game is essentially content complete; all that is left is QA, playtesting, and improving technical performance.

But Ohlen is not completely departing from Wizards of the Coast as a company. Ohlen will remain as a creative consultant for the tabletop publisher, shifting his focus to TTRPGs. This is a familiar field for Ohlen since he launched Arcanum Worlds, a TTRPG studio dedicated to publishing third-party material for Dungeons & Dragons.

Better still, Arcanum Worlds' output has a consistent record of quality. Their world includes DMs Guild supplements like Minsc and Boo's Journal of Villainy and Heroes of Baldur's Gate, as well as the comprehensive book on the Nine Hells, Chains of Asmodeus. The studio has also created original fantasy settings built on D&D's system, such as Raiders of the Serpent Sea and Odyssey of the Dragonlords.
